title: Tesla Cybercab Charging Sightings Suggest a Shift in How Autonomous Cars Stay Powered
description: Tesla's Cybercab prototype with a rear charging port sighting fuels debate over robotaxi charging strategies and what it means for deployment and urban EV infrastructure.
content:
[ELECTRIFICATION OF AUTO](https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/motoring)

[Technology](https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/technology)[Motoring](https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/motoring)

![Tesla Cybercab](https://d.ibtimes.co.uk/en/full/1787444/tesla-cybercab.jpg?w=736&f=709ec95dddcc91b31d1768b1c87ac207)

Screenshot from YouTube

Tesla's latest Cybercab charging sighting suggests a broader shift in how autonomous vehicles might stay powered in real-world operations. The unusual charging experience of a Tesla Cybercab prototype has stirred fresh debate within the EV and autonomous-vehicle communities, with a recent sighting of the vehicle's charging port—complete with a manual door and latch—raising questions about how Tesla might bridge its highly anticipated wireless charging vision with practical needs today.

First unveiled as a fully autonomous ride-hailing vehicle with no steering wheel or pedals, the Cybercab is meant to epitomise the future of robotaxis. However, the latest charging [footage](https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybercab-spotted-interesting-charging-solution-stimulating-discussion/) has revealed a more grounded approach to keeping these vehicles powered, at least during the early stages of deployment.

> 🚨 Tesla Cybercab charging port is in the rear of the vehicle!
>
> Here’s a great look at plugging it in!!
>
> [pic.twitter.com/SjbONjx5Iu](https://t.co/SjbONjx5Iu)
>
> — TESLARATI (@Teslarati) [January 29, 2026](https://twitter.com/Teslarati/status/2017022733247266897?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

## Prototype Sighting Fuels Discussion

In footage shared online earlier this week, observers noted the Cybercab's charging port is located at the rear of the vehicle, complete with a traditional manual door and latch. An employee is seen connecting the prototype to a Tesla Supercharger, prompting fresh speculation about the charging strategy Tesla may adopt as the vehicle moves towards production.
